>>2384195
With the exception of the Northwestern part of the state near Erie, the weather isn't terrible, but it's not great either. The Philadelphia area gets more sun but it gets pretty hot and humid in spring and summer. The Pittsburgh area tends to be overcast, wet, and snowy, mild in spring and summer. Everywhere else is somewhere in between the two. The "mountains" (big hills) run from Southwest to Northeast. East of the mountains gets Mid-Atlantic currents and West of the mountains gets some lake effect from the Great Lakes. Property values vary so much across the state. All of the areas I mentioned are deteriorating less than elsewhere in the state. Philly has a lot of crime, but as I said, it's really the only U.S. city comparable to Chicago or New York.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2367756
There's not much to tell. Probably a meme story on /trv. I went through a long list of terrible life events, both by my own fault and out of my control. Hated my job and considered quitting but I was terminated before I had the chance. I had severance pay and nothing else going for me. My apartment lease was up and I moved my stuff to storage, decided to go to Japan for a few months and maybe end it afterwards or along the way. Once in Japan, I spent a week or two adjusting, and I realized that having daily challenges in life made existential problems go on the back burner.
Met a girl on Tinder while it still was a "friend finder" in Asia. Used her as a tour guide and went to a love hotel a few times. It was casual and I met another girl, who was clingy and (I soon discovered) crazy. Met another. Made friends with Japanese guys and girls (and some expats) and developed a social circle - which didn't last longer than my trip, but amazed me by how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head.
Decided that life really wasn't so bad, at least as long as it stayed interesting. And decided not to kill myself and instead looked for ways to earn a living remotely. Applied for jobs until I got one.
In my opinion, the destination I chose was irrelevant. I'd often thought to myself "before I kill myself, I'll go to X country/location". They've varied over the years: California, Africa, India, Japan. When it was time, my destination was Japan. I guess I didn't really want to die because instead of taking the quick jump off an expressway bridge, I actually visited the destination I'd dreamed about. I'm glad I did, and now many years later, I've got kids and I'm happier than I've ever been before. Happier than many of my old friends back in my home country. I wouldn't change a thing.

>Best

>Athens, Greece
Never been somewhere so romantic yet so shitty. Gritty, dirty big city, juxtaposed against a majestic, historic and captivating place full of winding old streets. Beautiful beaches, weird commie anarchist neighbourhoods, vibrant music/arts/history, riot police on every corner at all times, crumbling post-modern architecture and beautiful outdoor cafes. Also beautiful girls, cheap whores and good food.

>Barcelona, Spain.
Not going to go down well on /trv/ but I’ve never had a bad vibe in this city. Big, cosmopolitan and international, modern yet loads of incredibly beautiful streets and neighbourhoods. Constantly has good events, great music/performance scenes and amazing restaurants/bars, imo some of the best in Europe.

In summer, Barcelona transforms into a sunny party city and attracts some of the most incredible women in the world and has one of the best party scenes in Europe.

One thing that I also like about Barcelona is the fact that it’s very much populated with normal, everyday Spanish people and families. Something that is pretty much lost on all of the other big international Western European cities.

>Worst
>Agadir, Morocco.

Filthy Islamic shithole from head to toe. Literally nothing redeeming, interesting or nice about the place. Full of scammers, child beggars, dirty beaches and disgusting food. No history, no historic architecture, zilch.

Literally the only redeeming aspect is the weather in Winter.

>London, England.
I’ve spent more time here than any of the aforementioned cities, IMO London is a soulless, godless place at this stage with very little of value left. Every time I even step foot in London at this point I get this crippling feeling of hopelessness and dread. The people, the local culture and everything in between is just off. It feels like an airport.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2367779
>It amazed me how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head

This is exactly why I urge people to go backpacking. When you spend a couple weeks (or months, or years) doing the backpacking thing, every day offers something new and you get a new perspective on your problems. I can't explain why, maybe it's because when you're backpacking you tend to make last minute decisions ("Fuck it, I'll skip Nice and take the train to Marseille!") and that makes you realise that you can make decisions about the more important things in your life too.
There is a phenomenon that astronauts come back to Earth with a greater interest in environmental concerns, altruism etc. Because seeing the whole world as just a ball of blue and green has some crazy effects on their beliefs. I think backpacking is kind of similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Favorite:
>Chhattisgarh, India: rural and predominately tribal state in east-central India. The whole area has a bad reputation for insurgency and violence, which keeps most visitors away. However, the entire region is incredibly beautiful, insofar it's heavily forested, mountainous, and incredibly biodiverse. It also has some of the most unique and isolated cultures in the entirety of "mainland" India. People are very, very friendly, but not in the obnoxious, quasi-autistic way that North Indians can be friendly. Locals can be a little suspicious of outsiders, but there's zero hassle or harassment. The tribals also make really good alcohol, kek
>Turkey: First country I ever visited outside of the United States. I went for the first time in 2013 and stayed in Istanbul for about a year in 2020-2021. IMO, it's one of the most-visited countries in the world for a reason: the people are extraordinarily hospitable, especially outside of big cities, and the entire country is drop-dead gorgeous. Istanbul is probably--and unironically--one of the most naturally beautiful urban areas in the world. Great views everywhere, reasonably safe, and cheap AF due to the ongoing lira crisis
>Colombia + Mexico: hard tie, can't really pick which I prefer. I'm not a coomer, I just really liked the sort of energy and vibrancy in most big, Latin American cities. If I had to choose one of the two, I'd probably go with Mexico, just because the food is so much better

picrel from a bike trip I took in east-central india earlier this year (sorry for crappy angle, don't have anything better on laptop and too lazy to transfer from phone)

>Athens

The center of Athens has been taken over by immigrants, mostly shitty Pakistanis and Bangladeshis. Greeks have fled the center of Athens to further away exurbs like Korydallos, Marousi, Kifissia, Lagonisi, Gylfada, etc.

In Athens the opposite of what is happening in most of the world is happening. Most the world has seen the city center being reclaimed by the rich and the professional yuppie class and their gentrifying, but in Athens the property market is the reverse, the city center is now a dump that is like an Islamic shitstain country and the outer areas of Athens are more expensive and sought after.

Finally this trip I spent much more time in the wealthier sections on the outer perimeter of Athens and the infrastructure still sucks, but it is nothing like the dystopia that is the Athens city center which is a mini Karachi or Dhaka at this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373726
Btw, I don't want to screw anyone over with this post:

I am not saying or recommending to stay at those exburbs which are further away from almost all the tourist destinations you will want to visit. They are also further from the cultural events if you know Greek.

If you have more money it is probably better to stay in Monastiraki or Plaka that are in the city center but still too expensive for the Islamic riff raff to swarm on the property market. If you have less money it is probably better to stay in Exarcheia which is much cheaper, but poor Greek hippies, arthouse types, anarchists and communists still live there which limits the Islamic floodgate.

I personally have chosen a hotel in the center of Pakistan in Greece, Metaxourgeio. But I know Greek and much more interested in participating in Greek language nightlife(theater, concerts, etc.) and the city center is still closer where most of those venues are located. The nearby subway also has just a few stops till it connects to Trainose(suburban rail line), Omonia, Syntagma, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
best
South Lake Tahoe. It's the most gorgeous place Ive ever seen. The lake is insane. Awesome outdoor bars. Amazing bike trails and hikes. But it still has a downtown area with a lot of good food and bars. Sitting around at the Hangar bar drinking beer by the fire at night under the stars is a vibe that's hard to match.

Jackson Hole Wyoming. The food is shockingly good. Every place in town is like a gourmet cowboy bar. You can do pretty much any outdoor outdoor activity. Whitewater rafting the snake river was one of the best experiences of my life. 3 days in Jackson Hole was not enough.

Maui. The best beaches Ive ever seen were in Makena on Maui. We found a condo for $300/night and that was a really good deal. I bought fresh fish a couple times and just grilled out to cut down on the outrageous restaurant bills we racked up. It's insanely expensive and we probably spent 4 grand on a 6 day trip for the 2 of us, but I felt like it was money well spent.

Worst
Portland Oregon. The memes are true. Portland is a homeless cesspool. There were homeless people camped out front of our Airbnb on a normal suburban street. It was one of the least charming cities Ive ever visited.

Atlantic City New Jersey. We parked the car and someone tried to sell us crack within 30 seconds. It's like vegas with none of the attractions but in the worst neighborhood you've ever seen.

Fresno California. You'll probably never go there, because why would you? I had to stay there for a conference. Your nightly choice of dining options are Dominoes Pizza, and a 24 hour McDonalds. It actually has worse crime than LA.There is literally NOTHING to do.

I’ve been to about 80 countries and I don’t think I genuinely hated any. Yeah there are up and downs but I have always found pleasant surprises. Some countries are better than others, for sure. Then there are countries I won’t really come back because I think I did most of it (tiny little ones).

Countries I liked the most:
- Paraguay: the memories of camping and herding cows with Paraguayan equivalent of gauchos in Chaco when I was kid still haunt me to this day.

- Iceland: did a multi-days trek in the middle of nowhere, in snowy volcanic landscape. Nothing is remotely similar.

- Extremadura in Spain, Yunnan in China in the early 00s, Chile, Lake Tahoe in Burgerland, some swampy place in Skåne Sweden (pic rel) etc. Too many things to list.

My latest trip was a road-trip in Netherlands. I liked it, I learned and saw a lot.
I love traveling so much bros.

>what has changed since 2019?
Forgot to answer this part. First in 2012, then far more substantially in 2019, the Chinese Communist Party forced the Hong Kong government to rewrite large parts of its legal framework (which was supposed to remain untouched until 2047) to align with Chinese law instead of the old British common law. Among other things, HK defendants can now be tried in Mainland China if the CCP demands it. It also purged the HK legislature of anyone who wasn’t fully sympathetic to the CCP.
>I thought they were dropping most of the covid regulations
Nope, just the mandatory quarantine period. Masks are still mandatory, even outside, and they still have a digital vaccine passport system in place with no end date in sight.

Best

>Lucerne, Switzerland.
Fucking awesome place, and a great middle ground between alpine city and country. Everything is gorgeous and the kapellbrucke is stellar, but the biggest problem is that everything is fucking expensive as shit, making you feel like a pauper next to all the wealth. My favorite place in the whole world.

>Bend, Oregon.
It's in a very tenuous place as people are beginning to discover it en-masse, but it's a pleasure to visit. Lots of places to go outdoors, lively town, and a young populace. Again, the problem is that granolas and remote techfags are flocking to it, so the future doesn't look so good. Also has the last Blockbuster in the world, which is neat.

>Molde, Norway.
I'm a bit biased because I have family here, but it's a cute town on the waterfront with lots of verticality. Easy to get to the countryside, and the atlantic road isn't far. Just a very pleasant place that follows the beat of its own drum. I'd visit another larger town as a tourist, however.

Turns out my favorite places are all mountainous and expensive. Go figure.

Worst

>San Francisco, California
The biggest tumor of a city I can think of. This is what happens when you have an idyllic region grow for too long, it begins to rot from the inside out. Worse yet, the tumor has metastasized and is starting to infect surrounding regions as well. Fuck this place.

>Milan, Italy
Dirty, expensive, and a worse italian version of Paris. Hosts a bunch of lazy migrants and faux posh italians who think they're above everyone else. The only nice parts are the duomo and last supper mural, and you can see those within a day. Go to Como or Lugano instead, those are FAR superior to this shithole.

>Aberdeen, Washington
No wonder Kurt sang into his shotgun, I would want to die if I had to live in this depressing hellhole too. So desolate and dreary on this part of the coast, and there's plenty of other A-tier places you can go instead if you want to see PNW nature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

i could very well be wrong about this, but i was thinking about the splash conversion the other day and i started thinking about what the probability could be that 70+% of the ride will remain intact and i white pilled myself into believing that the chances are good.
here's why; first of all production of new animatronics is expensive, and i'm sure imagineers were aware that projection mapped heads on limited motion bodies arent as well received as even the older practical style animatronics by both enthusiasts and the general public. this is true about projections in general. my boomer relatives have even remarked about this when they rode frozen ever after and mickey's runaway. they agreed that great movie ride was better and their reason was that the animatronics werent "real" and they looked like screens.
splash is renowned for two things, the drop and the animatronic driven theming and storyline. in order for the conversion to live up to the standard of its counterpart, it would need to keep most of the animatronics or really shell out enough from the budget to have at least half as many which is still a lot. and they cant just make them all projection mapped it would be an underwhelming presentation in comparison to what the ride was before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378097
now add in the fact that most of the ride's layout lends itself to the way the indoor sets are built into the building. thats big money to change all that.
i think what we are likely to see in the end could be compared to what the skinning of Haunted Mansion into Holiday is like.
Most of the ride will remain the same and feel the same but the theming will be different. The America Sings animatronics will stay, the whole damn riverboat will stay, brer fox and bear animatronics could be repurposed but also could go completely but if they do go, those will be the tiana projection mapped ones that drive the story but they will be in the same spots as the old ones and all the sets will be in the same spots they will just be reskinned.
the reason i believe all this is not just because of the logistics of cost vs meeting high expectations but because it just would make more sense to do it that way, and keep the experience as familiar as possible while still transforming it into something new.if i'm wrong and this ride is frozen ever after 2.0 then i will at least be right about how it will be perceived by the public. many people didnt even know what maelstrom was called, and they only recalled some sort of boat ride at epcot that they mostly remembered as being in the mexico section. Splash has a bit higher status than that, and they know it. they are not even going to change it as much as they changed maelstrom, and i gotta admit when i ride it now, all im thinking about the whole time is "that's where the trolls were" and "thats where the polar bear was standing as you drifted backward and it disappeared into the darkness".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378206
flume rides are relatively non-complicated ride systems which can be updated and refurbished fairly easily and inexpensively which is why so many parks have had the same flume rides for 40+ years.
Add in the fact that Hopkins rides still exists and manufactures parts and there is little reason why parks would replace these rides when they are still massively popular and can be maintained whenever they need to be for not a lot of effort or cost.
In the case of Splash its especially practical to preserve its ride system not only because of the way it was built into its surrounding structure but because the layout is a massive hit with the public and would be difficult to match if they were to come in with some water coaster or something that would shorten the length of the ride and take away from the compatibility for the rides theming to be in sync with the pace of the ride etc.
Replacing Splash's ride system would be a huge mistake and a costly one at that, even for disney.

>i think roller coasters are cooler than theming but theming for the roller coaster is ok but i dont really care about walking around in a themed park i'd rather go through an actual park
The people who go to theme parks to walk around and me immersed by theming really should consider going to actual parks (like national parks in the US). Immerse yourself in real natural beauty, not fake rock work. Some people go to Epcot just to walk around the themed countries and eat and drink and IMO that's not worth the admission price. You can do the same at the themed Vegas Strip casinos for free.

I think most of the general public doesn't care about theming. They're there for the rides. Disney World fans make a big deal about the resort as a whole and the non-park aspects, but none of that would exist without the theme parks. Over half of the parks are 1 day visitors from off property. They're not there to walk around and people watch, ride a couple rides and go back to the hotel, they're there all day to ride as many rides as possible. Coasters being among the most popular rides whether they're themed or not.

I think a little theming helps. For example, Steel Vengeance has a mining back story in the queue and its overall look fits the nearby themed frontier town. I think this works a lot better than a parking lot coaster. Cedar Point is unique in that it's on a peninsula surrounded by Lake Erie (and a marina entrance), has a giant sandy beach, and its marquee coasters offer fantastic views of these things.

Last one was 2 years ago EDITION

>Why Taiwan ?
why not ? it's Asia on easy level, tons of friendly people, nicest expat community that isn't weeb or druggies or coomers

>No, seriously, why ?
Great emphasis on industry so all engineers are welcome
They recruit a lot of TEFL and it's relatively well paid compared to the average salary on the island, great if you don't have any student debt to deal with
Taipei is absolutely gorgeous, the skyline may not be up to standards compared to the megacities of Asia but it's a nice place with all the amenities of a world-class city
Rent is relatively cheap compared to the other big places in Asia, easily comparable to Thailand (albeit with a roughly 20% markup)
Street food is cheap and delicious
Taiwan has a rich and multicultural history that allows them to be ok with the concept of being a foreigner

>Is Taiwan the real China ?
No, ROC isn't the real china, it's an offshoot as much as the PRC is. Taiwan has been impacted by japanese culture a lot whereas the PRC modified radically china's culture through the cultural revolution. Both represent significant aspects of the Chinese civilization and you should go to both if you're truly interested.

>How can I immigrate/expatriate/live in Taiwan ?
Work Visa, Working Holiday Visas, Gold Card Visa, Student visa, and Chinese Student visa. and whatever investor scheme i can't be arsed to look up. Always make sure you consult your local Taiwanese embassy (likely referred as a taipei representative office in your country). Keep in mind the latter two make you eligible for a couple of grants and allow you to work (you need a work permit but it's easy to get).

>cooming in taiwan ?
the prostitutes are ridiculously expensive (actually true, a hundred bucks an hour) so please don't come

>Will China bomb Taiwan ?
Not yet. Several conditions must be fulfilled and right now, very few are.

591.com.tw is the way to go but it's in mandarin and the landlord may not want to speak english, but facebook has many facebook groups. The price of 1000$ for a one bedroom appartment is ridiculously high. As for being old buildings, that's pretty much what you're getting in taiwan i'm afraid.

>1500$ per month for the appartment
That's the point of shared rental. You risk more by having more tenants to deal with but you earn more. There rarely is a shared appartment whose combined rents is lower or equal to that of a single rental, so it's far from accurate to get an estimate that way.

It also depends on where you're looking. Lots of rental on da'an and xinyi district but they're expensive and not quite worth it. I usually recommend zhongzheng district as the go to for westerners, it's easier to move and lots of good food and neighborhoods. While being p cheap.

What people do and what i did was to resign myself to a 6 month bail in a shared appt at 300$ then i asked the taiwanese pals i made by then to help me out with facilitating me with the appartment i currently live in, that is tad more modern and great looking for a reasonably cheaper square foot.

>Where can I stay and have a nice time

A guy made a cool map on another thread.

>the problem with the taiwanese downtown is that it spans half the fucking city with many nevralgic centers (Dongmen, Ximen, 101, Technology Building, Main Station, Digital Plaza around Songjiang Nanjing etc.). So as long as you're within the city limits (even if you're not, you're never THAT far), It'll take you as much time to walk to the station than to get to your station of choice. I highly suggest living near the green line (so, the green zone) because that practically gets you anywhere and is well connected to the red Line (which basically covers the more expensive Da'an area). You could also consider living up north where the black area is. This is where a lot of older expats live, but i don't know much about it besides Yuanshan with its Maji Square (and its Triangle)

You want cheap but nice addresses, look around Wanshan and Zhongzheng District. If that's too much, you can still settle for something around Xindian without missing out on the rest of Taipei since it's not that far. Also, the 648 bus basically goes from the deeper end of xindian all the way to City Hall, so even if you're a cheap hack you can make do with that. Because yes, knowing how the buses work in Taipei will save you a *lot* of money.

>>2375127
Taipei 101 is definitely worth visiting. There's also the linjiang night market nearby too. Also, elephant mountain is a bit of a climb but the view is worth it.

Also, Taipei main station has some very cool underground malls, more precisely Beimen Station. You can find lots of weeb stuff there as well as some nice goodies and souvenirs you can bring with you. In general, if you're not planning to go to Japan any time soon, Taiwan in general is a great source of weeb shit you can gift or keep for yourself.

All the night markets to visit are omnipresent on the internet so i won't bother you with them.

Definitely go to Ximending, it's a nice bustling neighborhood. There's also the Guanghua digital plaza if you're looking for electronics. Definitely haggle if you're there. They've got great deals.

The Gongguan river park is really nice this time of year, definitely rent some bikes and go there, it's really nice. The Gongguan area in general is my favorite, they've got the best all you can eat hotpots too and there's NTU too. Also, the neighborhood around Technology building (north of NTU and gongguan) is good looking with lots of cool restaurants.

I highly recommend the museums too. CKS memorial, palace museum, etc.

Oh and definitely try to escape taipei for an evening and plan a trip to Keelung.

just go with libgen using unblockit (google it). you've got both volumes. workbook and textbook
You don't need a dedicated grammar textbook for chinese. You can go with the HSK textbook (for simplified) or the NTNU traditional chinese textbook. Those are the ones people work with, meaning if you're looking to be taught later, the teachers will familiar with either one of those depending on where they're from.
When you learn a language like Chinese you're better off following the beaten path. Just do whatever the people around you do and stick to it.
Also, i don't think you should care about the difference until you get 2, 3 years unless there is an urgent need to improve. They don't give a fuck about you being the Jodie Foster of Chinese.


>>2379257
When I said there wasn't any tae kim equivalent i didn't mean that there weren't any textbooks you could check out. Tae Kim's grammar guide is dedicated to grammar because Japanese requires a rundown if you want to say even the simplest of shit. Also, "the nuance and subtleties" are irrelevant when you're a beginner. work on it hard for like a year and a half, get the basics. The only thing you have to worry about is to orally recognize the fucking words because chinese is spoken very fast outside of classes and the taiwanese have a lisp-y accent that can get very confusing. I mean fuck, just get your TONES right to start with. You'll sound like Tarzan but you'll at least be intelligible.

If you're going to Taipei ? Go to the NTNU (normal taiwan uni near Guting station) library and purchase "A course in Contemporary Chinese". It's the one I used to study, and it's basically THE standard traditional textbook here in Taiwan, and getting a physical copy along with the workbook is good advice.
You can find it on libgen too in the meantime. Don't waste your time learning simplified if you know you're going to taiwan. The switch is hard.

>>2378143
You're wrong. You can get a room in Seville for like $400 a month, I know someone who is doing this. It's a nice college town, young sluts come from all over Europe on Erasmus.

If a Latino immigrant making 10€/hr picking strawberries can make it in Spain, you can too, ffs. You could get a room in a tier-one city like Madrid for like 700 bucks.

You just have to know where to look for an apartment. Don't use AirBnb for anything other than the short term. Go on local Facebook groups and ask where to get started looking.

If people find out you have a remote American income they'll be lining up to rent to you. I met a Brazilian guy willing to rent to me for $40 a night at the height of the tourist season in Barcelona. If you looked online you'd hardly be able to find anything for less than $200, if you were able to find anything at all. Wasn't a bad part of town either, even though in Spain "the bad part of town" is an absolute joke in terms of danger compared to the US, Latin America, France, etc.

You do have to be aware of scams. If a nigger starts video calling you asking for a deposit on a place you haven't been to, don't give him anything.

I've found that Spain is a nice middle ground for someone looking to live large on a remote income. It's a safe, clean white country that is full of attractive women, very cosmopolitan with a vast cultural wealth at the same time. The nightlife is out of this world. I was able to eat out twice a day and get drunk every night when I went, and I make less than $100k. Yes, it's difficult if you depend on the local economy to make a living, but if you make your money abroad it's an option that is definitely worth considering.

How are you going to bake in hostels? You're better off either having a remote job that lets you move about or busking. Alternative is settling in one place, maybe volunteering for hostel. Then finding some job you can dump in a paycheck or two. The problem is governments hate people and will need tax ID's, documents, etc. But you could work somewhere for half a year while living in a hostel and fucking lots of easy girls while preparing to travel for the remainder. I used to work at a hostel, usually they ask between 15 and 20 hours per week. Sometimes it's doing beds, some cleaning (not to highest standard, so easy) or very basic reception stuff. In Europe you'd benefit from learning languages, even to a basic level. You're not going to find a temporary job with just English alone. Even A1 is probably enough to wash dishes or do tables. You could try cooking meals and selling them to guests in hostel, but I imagine most people would rather eat out + the hostel might take offence at you doing your own hustle there.

tl;dr
busk
remote work
temporary settling with some shitter job

those are your best bets unless you're really creative and can come up with something.

If there's a will there's a way as they say.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2383225
I have the same problem and have found a way to cope with it. Believe me, I tried everything. Xanax, sleeping pills, alcohol, weed, everything, nothing really did it, and actually weed and alcohol just amplified my paranoia. No matter how strong the sleeping pills, I couldn't fall asleep. I know this will sound stupid and people will probably shit on me, but meditation is what helped me. It's not like some hippie dippy shit. The part that scares me the most is takeoff. So what I do is start counting in my head when takeoff starts and don't stop until we're in the air and stabilized. I empty my mind of everything else except for the count and don't allow myself to focus on the strange sounds the sensation of the ground falling out from under me. I do the same thing whenever there's turbulence - just count until it's over. This might not work for you, but there are lots of ways to meditate. I know it might sound stupid but it really has helped me tremendously. I still hate flying but I don't let it stop me anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2383265
It doesn't matter, that shit does not help you conquer your fear and I'm tired of everyone parroting this shit. The fear of flying is not something rational and appealing to logic and fact does not just magically make it go away. It's not even just the fear of being high in the air, it's the complete lack of control over your fate that makes flying terrifying. Cars might be more dangerous, but at least you're the one behind the wheel. I would also venture to guess that most of us have been in a minor car crash; but a minor plane crash is comparatively rarer. Even if you think, "Oh, this is way safer than xyz," there's always that nagging feeling in the back of your mind saying, "But what if this is the exception, what if the pilot makes a mistake, what if something goes wrong." You can't conquer a fear of the dark by saying, "There's nothing out in the dark, you're way safer out in the dark than in a Walmart" or something, it's not anything rational or logical, it's a primal fear. The only way to conquer is to actually fly and make the unfamiliar familiar. Something I also do is actually research the history of flight and the engineering that goes into a plane. I think, "Wow, what an amazing piece of human ingenuity," instead of "This is a fucking metal death trap."

I don't just mean injured in a car, I mean you are more likely to DIE in a car accident compared to dying in a plane accident.

There is plenty outside of your control in a car. You could be a passenger. You could be driving next to a drunk, you cannot control the people around you. You don't know if the servicing was done correctly or if you're brakes are just about to break.

Planes are serviced to extremely high standards. There are many fail safes with respect to backup control systems, extra fuel, flight authorities.

Also a plane is largely controlled by computers now, there is little room for human error.

Rationality is all that matters, if you have irrational fears then overcome them.

>>2383889
>Fly Qantas. They have never had an air crash
Qantas had four fatal crashes between 1946 and 1951. They have not had a fatal crash in the jet era. In 1999 QF1 (747-400) overran the runway in bad weather at BKK, effectively damaging the aircraft beyond serviceability. There were no serious injuries or facilities in that incident but Qantas wrote the hull off and I believe the Captain was fired. In 2010 QF32 (A380) suffered an uncontained engine failure, shrapnel from the engine damaged the port fuel tank causing a fuel leak, it also caused damage to the hydraulic systems and control surfaces of the port wing. They made an emergency landing in Singapore, there were no injuries or fatalities but this had the potential to become a major incident.

>>2380104
just going to give you possible ideas here, as to what I’d do in this situation.

Firstly, if you’ve got cash or a card you can easily stay in a hostel. Yeah you might lose money on your AirBnB, not a big deal. You have somewhere to stay.

Secondly, I’d reach out to AirBnB, I’m sure they have an emergency contact number you can reach. Getting hold of a telephone shouldn’t be hard. Call them and let them know of the situation, that you’ve had all of your stuff stolen and have nowhere to stay. I’m sure they’ll give you the address based on your account, the relevant contact and so fourth, so long as you have the email as well as a few other security questions.

If that fails, if you booked with a credit card such as Amex, they might be able to help in situations like this. Not guaranteed, but always a major plus.

If you have travel insurance, they should cover the phone, and there’s a possibility that they could cover the cost as a result of that.

Not sure what else to add, just use common sense bro.

Use 1pass for all 2FA OTPs.

>I heard they have the worse return tourist rate (5%) of the SEA countries. Why don't tourists return to Vietnam?
1. Most people who would do return trips after crossing off all the major sights from their list are either sex pests or resort tourists. Vietnam is garbage for both. The cooming offer is nowhere close to its neighbors and the beaches are frankly shit. While they can seem nice at a first glance, Vietnam is drowning in trash and has zero water pollution standards. You'll be frolicking in the waves and suddenly there's literal shit all around you.
2. People are often plain rude. There's little in the way of etiquette and the concept of disturbing others (which is generally a problem with SEA, but not to that level) does not exist in Vietnam at all. They'll spit, cut the line and play shitty Tik-Tok vids on full volume at 3AM on a night bus if they feel like it. Everyone working in the tourist industry has nothing but utmost contempt for tourists and will make sure you know that.
3. Scams. 80% of all Vietnamese you'll interact with will lie through their teeth in an attempt to extract money from you. If you don't play along, they'll get loud, insistent and aggressive. You can easily get ripped off in Thailand, which has ten times the return rate, but they usually do it with a smile and try to make sure you won't notice. Vietnam is on the level of people blatantly telling you to fuck off and demanding double while you point at the price list right behind them.
Don't take me wrong, Vietnam's my favorite place in SEA, but it is, without any doubt, a rude shithole that is the very opposite of comfy and that relaxed holiday feeling is what people are usually looking for.

Serious answer:

I found that Vietnam doesn't really have much to do for a tourist as far as big sites are concerned, and what they do have is very spread out. The attraction to Vietnam is mostly the entire country itself, the hostel culture and vibe was good but I don't think that gets people to come back, I enjoyed Vietnam but wouldn't return because I feel like I got everything I needed out of it.

Big tourist sites are Phong Nha Caves, Ha Long bay, Hai Van pass, Ha Giang loop, a few museums in Hanoi and Saigon. All of these are hundreds of miles apart and the transportation in the country is slow as fuck to get anywhere. It's not like Europe where you can show up in a capitol and have tons to do.

Also the English proficiency in the country sucks, the only people who could speak English were hostel workers and some extremely tourist focused restaurants in Hanoi. I went to large international catering hotels where they had 1 receptionist there who could barely speak any English, obviously I don't expect every rice farmer on the side of the road to speak perfect English but when nobody can it isn't good for tourists.

t. Spent 1 month in Vietnam, motorcycled Saigon to Hanoi

There's a high speed train between Vientiane and the border with China. Actually it goes into China once the Chinese border fully reopens which seems to be getting close.

That's your best bet for public transport between Vientiane, Vang Vieng, Luang Prabang and further north.

To get to the Plain of Jars you'd probably want tot ake a plane. Bus is always available but not great obviously. Some roads are rough.

You can also take boats on the Mekong between difft towns. That's sometimes best option.

Within cities you have standard tuktuks and taxis. They hvae apps now for everything too.

They get a lot of tourists so English is fine if you are within cities and tourist areas.

Business class is;
1. Qatar QSuites (only on 777 at the moment, which is a minority of their flying aircraft)
2. Singapore any aircraft in service (A380 or A350 long haul is slightly the best IMO)

Cathay used to be very good, but it's unclear where they sit now after years of not doing anything, need to test it out.

You can get from one side of Israel to the other in a 6-7 hour drive.

There's a 1-3 hour drive to the Negev desert from Jerusalem. The Ramon crater is also pretty cool as desert settings go.

Also, Jerusalem has a nightlife scene that "competes" with Tel Aviv.

Since you're coming during "winterish" times, I highly recommend you go north and see Golan Heights. Amazing scenery and as a tourist, you will be welcome in the near Arab cities and experience some great food.

If you have a night in Tel Aviv, get some top-tier weed and go for a hipster culture and drinks spree.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i assume the points on the map are stops you are making?
Are all destinations locked in or just a general loop?
What sort of things do you have planned to do?
What classic europe trip stuff are you not into?
What types of things do you think you're into

Is Zurich a planned stop?
Because a cool route from Munich is south route to Innsbruk Austria, to Italy thru Dolomite mountains - Bolzano (Nearby bressanone, ortisei, merano - famous parks for ex puez odle) to Trento, along Lake Garda, to Verona (one of my fav cities).
From Verona (this could also be connected on your Zurich to Milan route) is a transverse northern italy trainline.
Venice - Padua - Vicenza - Verona - Pescheria Del Garda - Brescia - Bergamo - Milan - Turin. Italians autisitcally hate the northern cities but as a foreigner i thought they were pretty comfy but as with everywhere it is usually cooler outside the city.
The italian northern lakes are very popular so if you are going from zurich to genoa as on the map - you're passing near lake lugano between lake maggiore and lake como, both have beautiful towns, but summer in italy famous spots will have tourists naturally. other northern lakes as mentioned garda but the lower tier ones are beautiful too like iseo or orta
Are you going to Genoa area or were just thinking to travel along the riviera all the way to barcelona? South of milan is Pavia - old city with a few landmarks.
other direction there is cinque terre but will be crowded. There are many popular tourist towns on italian riviera, Portofino is a fancy one.
Like every region there are tiny beautiful towns, like Dolceacqua or Apricale - but is it worth the time getting there on a tight schedule with public transport? depends if you are taking a break or seek those things.
Drive italian riviera to french riviera is nice.
In france before Nice there are towns of Menton, Eze. This area has the roads called Les Trois Corniches

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
From Germany, There is the Romantic Road - in Bavaria, it is a tourist track that all the towns kind of have comfy romantic architecture but if you were coming from Prague - Nuremberg or Regensburg have good medeival town centres. A bit further off route there is wurzburg too. Rothenburg ob der Taber is probably super popular tourist spot but it was cool.

If you got to Munich area - for a detour, Salzburg was pretty comfy, there is also the austrian lake district outside salzburg most famous town is hallstadt,
Also in that direction there is Chiemsee - a lake in germany has an unfinished 1800s palace on an island. There is hitler's eagles nest hideout too.
South of munich there are touristy bavarian mountain towns at the foot of the mountains like zugspitze you could get cable car up that.
Near the town of Fussen there is the Neuschwanstein Castle
On your map you go near Lindau before going into switzerland -is an island town.

If you drive through french riviera towards marseille, there are the famous fancy towns like cannes and saint tropez but traffic might be congested by them but inland in that area is also beautiful. and if you are looking to see beautiful south french coast, just before marseille are the Calanques of Marseille. Verdon national park has a nice canyon river. If you look in the countryside of any place you'll find weird things like Malpasset Dam - a collapsed dam disaster, maybe not interesting to everyone but if i was in the neighborhood itd be cool.
Towns like Arles, Orange, Nimes have a large intact roman structure or two. Avignon famous for the french pope + its bridge song. Pont Du Gard aqueduct.
In June Provence lavender fields start to blum - Plateau de Valensole is a famous region. They also have sunflowers. There are too many villages in every region of france that if you were on a road trip could be worth passing through. some cool looking ones are like Moustiers-Sainte-Marie, Gordes, Roussillon, Les Baux-de-Provence

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Carcassonne is a famous tourist spot - the classic fairytale castle vibe has been recreated here i think in 1800s reconsturction.

Millau is like one of the largest bridges in the world or something.

Albi has a neat history - grand cathedral built to establish catholic presence, there was another sect of christianity Cathars that were put down centred in Albi

Going into Spain, Girona is a medieval town that is famous as a foodie destination, has some film+tv shoots there.
Castellfollit de la Roca is a cool looking village in the country, and Besalú
North of Barcelona there is Montserrat monestary in the mountian
Tarragona has roman amphitheatre, and an aquaduct

Going thru middle of switzerlnd, Interlaken is the most famous area. As mentioned Lauterbrunnen - it is like fairytale land with high waterflls off the mountains. Grindelwald also famous. gelmerbahn looks neat to try - there are a lot of cogwheel trains for steep mountains in switzerland.
Famous ski destinations are nice in summer too - like Zermatt (Matterhorn) is an alpine town that has no civilian traffic, you have to train into town.
A bit in the wrong direction but Stelvio Pass road into italy is quite famous.
Valle Verzasca is sometimes clickbait called Maldives of Milan - north of Locarno, the crystal blue river, there is a famous bridge ponte dei salti

>going to Malmo, Sweden
Pray you dont get grenades thrown at you or outright fucked with as its a no-go zone for police.

France and it's stops should be the biggest time spender on your trip. Cut out Spain and do north Italy proper instead or cut out Italy and do north Spain properly rather than rushing it. Reloop into east France and go to Switzerland after. Prague is a 3 day city, Munich and its surroundings are really nice. Poland is a meme stop with this itinerary, you should cut from Prague back home through Germany.

You're severly underestimating how much time you need per stop. My 9 stops in France can easily take up 3 weeks and that's still semi-rushed. Your itinerary now looks like a 1 day per stop deal, at which point you're better off not going at all.

This OP. I did a motorcycle trip through the alps a couple of years ago and took a similar route to balzano and other places in the vicinity before going up through Switzerland.

Northern Italy was by far my favorite. The dolomites are amazing (pic related). The Swiss alps are very majestic and the roads are of superior quality but the smaller roads are far more comfy and Switzerland is also twice as expensive as Italy.
I'd skip it entirely if going back, but if you absolutely want to visit I would just drive through for the vistas, the hike in prices annoyed me so much I just camped out and bought sandwiches from convenience stores until I got back to Germany (which was still more expensive than restaurants on the Italian side.

Yep, if I could live in Spain but keep my Swiss salary I would move there happily. A Spanish guy who works for my wife actually relocated with his family back to Madrid, and he flies back into Switzerland four days a week so he doesn’t have to go back to the Spanish pay scale with the company. It’s a better deal for him to rent a studio apartment in Switzerland (not cheap) and fly twice a week (on EasyJet, so this is presumably pretty cheap) than it would be for him to be officially based back at the Spanish office he was hired from.

During the pandemic my wife’s department at her company officially went “location-agnostic” to allow people to work from wherever they wanted (her boss, for example, lives in NYC, and my wife has people based all over Europe reporting to her), so we thought for a minute about relocating to Portugal (we’re not Europeans, so it’s one of not many countries where it would be easy to get permanent residency if we were to abandon our Swiss permits), but when the company introduced the caveat that people had to be paid local salaries unless they were on site 4X/week we scrapped the idea.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2324511
Neuquen is pretty much a big city now, isn't really that isolated, and has great landscapes.

Rio Negro is a bit more snowy, so naturally there's fewer urban areas, but still quite populated.

Chubut and Santa Cruz are pretty much full of industries and huge distances between every landmark. Would recommend it if you like isolation, snow and driving in it.

Otherwise, I would recommend Buenos Aires. You have the big city but there's also a lot of countryside to make your house there. About 100km you can choose exactly the amount of tranquility you're looking for depending on how far from tourist areas you want to go. Also, it's a lot cheaper to live there. Southern provinces are quite expensive. Pretty much the same as living in Europe.

posts.com:
Argie here, I'm seeing a handful of misconceptions about this place and the surrounding countries, so I'll clarify a couple things. Feel free to ask about anything else you have doubts about.

For one, this is not a "globohomo-free" country. Quite the opposite, in fact. Save for Uruguay, this is the most pozzed country in latin america. The government is more preoccuppied with preventing "hateful discourse" and forcing a butchered "inclusive" version of the spanish language than taking care of the one half of our population who's living below the poverty line. Not to mention most sides of the political spectrum haven't necessarily adopted but have at least accepted and allowed this shit to happen.
A second thing to note, I have no idea why you'd want to live in a country that has been edging at the brink of economic collapse for decades. Unless you feel like Lord Miles wasn't enough of a retard, I see no reason to leave your home to come live in a place like this. Also, you better like taxes, because you're gonna see a lot of them.
As for the surrounding countries, Uruguay has a great quality of life and everything outside Montevideo is fucking empty. Paraguay and Bolivia are alright, they're somehow less corrupt and more stable than we are. Chile is good, they recently elected a leftie, so people are panicking about them going the way of Venezuela and yours truly, but if you ask me, he seems like a very down-to-earth guy when compared to the usual, blind, retarded ideologues every other country gets when they elect a left-wing politician.

Ask away if you wanna know anything about the people, climate, living standards, etc. of any particular province/region.

>>2328122
Yup, government sponsored, too.

Back in the day when the country got its independence, our caudillos (pretty much spanish for "warlord") raided the south and genocided the shit out of every native tribes they could find. Somehow, this one survived and ended up becoming a what's essentially a cold war-style left-wing guerrilla terrorist group.

Once every few weeks, you'll hear of them terrorizing the people living in and around Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, and rarely Santa Cruz and southern Mendoza. They're always fighting with locals and "reclaiming" land belonging to the mapuche nation (look up "wallmapu" to see the extent of their larp).
The government, being your typical, run-of-the-mill leftie activist group, loves turning a blind eye to it. The last bit of news I remember hearing about is them intervening to take land away from the army to give it to one of these groups and the ensuing shitstorm that followed. Last year they spent like a whole month raiding the town of El Bolsón, to the point the locals got tired of nobody doing shit and took it in their own hands to literally ride on horses and hunt them down cowboy style. It was pretty surreal.

That said, it's not unlivable. Many popular tourist destinations are smack-dab in the middle of mapuche territory. Their numbers are far smaller here than in Chile, so the real problem lies on the other side of the Andes, it's just that here they have free reign to fuck with people.
If you see pic related, stay wary.

>how's the crime in the smaller cities and towns?
There used to be places here where there wasn't much to fear years ago, but the country is going downhill hard, so those places are starting to feel it.
That said, it will be less common than in the big cities. I won't say anywhere near zero, but it's harder to get away with shit when the place is small and everybody knows each other, lel. Town life is mostly chill, but far poorer depending on where you go (the north especially).
>Let's say a town of about 10k -- is there cartel bullshit going on there, or in any of the countryside?
Doubt it, most of the drug trafficking happens around/in the outskirts of the bigger cities (the exception being Rosario, where the WHOLE city is the argentinian equivalent of a mexican narco state, stay the fuck away).
>Do you feel safer in general in the smaller towns than you do in the cities?
Crime can always happen. You will be more "exposed" in small towns and you might be in trouble if you're hurt badly or feel unsafe at a particular moment in time, because small town hospitals have few resources and not as many policemen, while you'll be more prone to it in the cities but at least there are more resources/people to help you. "Safety" kinda depends on how much you can fend for yourself.
>How are the real estate prices there compared to La Tierra de las Hamburguesas?
Don't know much about that, actually, but I can tell you two things:
-Buenos Aires has been having problems reminiscent to that of London this year. Shit is too expensive and too small, so nobody wants it.
-As for the whole country in general, prices are just going up like everything else, so if you're planning to buy something, make sure you bring in as much foreign currency as you can so you don't have to start collecting Monopoly money that will have both lost its value and fallen short of the new price by the time you have it.

>>2327930
Tons of options, red meat in general is awesome but there's also exceptionally good pizzas and ice cream. You can eat a 4-star meal for less than 10 usd.
As for more traditional foods, you can try locro, empanadas, guiso, and if you like sweet stuff, anything with dulce de leche. Like alfajores or facturas that you can buy in panaderias. Croissants with dulce de leche are a must.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2327930
And about the drinking there's pretty good regional beer, and the last decade breweries have opened everywhere in most cities. IPA, APA, scottish, pale, etc.
I don't personally drink wine, but Argentinian wine is highly regarded as one of the best in the world. I've seen tourists praise even the cheap ones.
Decent whisky, outside of your typical brands
Not much vodka, tequila or rum, even though there is enough variety
And then there is Fernet. Mixed with Coke. Oh boy, it has a strong taste so it's a hit or miss, but if it hits, it's heaven.

If you're wondering about non-añcoholic drinks, meh. I guess we have mate, which is an infusion, sorta like herb tea, served on a wooden bowl (also called mate). It's more of a social thing, people sit together and pass the mate around, while chilling, or eating some snacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

However, the locals are very helpful, especially if you look like you're having difficulties plus it's still cheap enough to hire a private guide+driver, so you'll be able t dictate the pace and only exhaust yourself where it cannot be avoided.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

Yes, the road between Dushanbe and Khujand is the major road of Tajikistan, so they go through great pains to keep it open the whole year.
On the way you'll pass through the infamous Anzob tunnel, nicknamed "the tunnel of death" because it was operating for ten year while unfinished, but since about 2016 this is not the case any more, now it's just another long tunnel with the usual traffic dangers present in the region.

If you want to be absolutely sure to keep to your schedule you can plan to go via Termez/Samarkand/Oybek in Uzbekistan, their roads and rails are open all year round without major problems.

The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.
Even women with a liberal worldview are sexually conservative and like to show off their housewife skills by wanting to feed you with food they cook, showing off their bargaining skills or even offering to fix the shirt you tore during your date.
You will also quickly get to know her brothers/cousins/friends who will invite you to their activities consisting of drinking, smoking and all kinds of sports and physical activities to judge you for themselves.
Speaking Russian and/or the local language will definitely help your chances in all stages of the process.
